journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Technical University of Denmark, Lyngby, Denmark

author-notes.corresp: Jørgen J Jensen, Technical University of Denmark, Section of Maritime Engineering, Building 101E, Lyngby DK-2800, Denmark. Email: jjj@mek.dtu.dk

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on Hydroelasticity Theories and Applications

abstract.p: It is important to include the contribution of the slamming-induced response in the structural design of large vessels with a significant bow flare. At the same time it is a challenge to develop rational tools to determine the slamming-induced loads and the prediction of their occurrence. Today it is normal practice to apply a standard sea-keeping procedure to determine the relative velocity distribution between the water surface and the hull and then to estimate the bottom slamming loads and the bow-flare slamming loads based on two-dimensional formulations similarly to water-entry problems. The pressure distribution as well as the total force is then determined by integration over a pseudo-three-dimensional presentation of the hull geometry.
In this paper the evaluation of the slamming load is taken one step further by performing direct three-dimensional, fully non-linear numerical calculations in a realistic wave environment.

Both the global and the local slamming loads are assessed numerically using a finite-volume formulation with the free surface captured by a volume-of-fluid technique. This numerical procedure is justified by comprehensive validation studies where numerically evaluated slamming pressures are compared with experimentally measured results.

To obtain an insight into the three-dimensional flow effects the next step is to apply the validated numerical procedure to evaluate and compare the accuracy and performance of the traditionally used two-dimensional formulations by a comparison with three-dimensional numerical formulations for a fine-form Panamax container ship bow hitting a flat water surface at a constant trim angle.

Finally, the slamming evaluation is carried out on the basis of a three-dimensional case study of the same container ship sailing in a head sea at half the service speed in a critical wave episode which is defined conditional on a given extreme response level of the hull girder bending moment.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Slamming-induced hull girder whipping is known to lead to significant contributions to the extreme hull girder loads for large ships in heavy seas.1 At present, the main design loads on merchant ship hulls are based on rules developed by the classification societies. These rules do not explicitly take into account slamming-induced whipping loads. Therefore, there is a need to develop new design-oriented prediction tools which can be used in the initial design phase to develop analysis tools to predict the magnitude of the slamming-induced forces in the hull girder.

Much research has been presented in the literature on the slamming pressures and the resulting hull girder response. Starting in the 1970s, a theory2–6 was developed for a unified treatment of the combined effect of the wave-frequency hull girder response and the high-frequency whipping response. These theoretical studies were based on a non-uniform beam theory with a strip theory to represent the fluid actions. In more recent years, progress has been made on numerical calculations based on comprehensive three-dimensional (3D) time simulations coupled with finite-element models (see, for example, the papers by various researchers7–12). However, even if coupled 3D hydroelastic codes exist, they are not yet sufficiently mature for design calculations based on long-term operational profiles.

Our conclusion is that there is still no well-established practical procedure to determine the total response of ship hull girders to the slamming loads combined with the non-linear low-frequency loads in realistic sea conditions. Because of the random and transient nature of these loads, the solutions become complex and existing procedures are not yet suitable for routine engineering evaluations.

Steps towards the development of a practical design procedure for the whipping response have been presented by Jensen et al.13 and by Pedersen and Jensen.14 They showed that, when the impact duration was short compared with the period of the two-node natural hull girder vibration mode, then relatively simple procedures for probabilistic distributions of short-term as well as long-term whipping loads could be developed, provided that the slamming impulse loads could be predicted in a rational way. In the above-mentioned references an empirical factor was applied for the combined effect of a two-dimensional (2D) approximation to the 3D flow effects and for the longitudinal extent of the slamming area.
It is the purpose of the present paper to contribute to the derivation of a more rational procedure for practical calculations of the impulse caused by the slamming loads.

Throughout the present paper the slamming pressures are assessed numerically using a finite-volume formulation with the free surface captured by a volume-of-fluid (VOF) technique. The numerical analyses are based on the Navier–Stokes equations with an additional transport equation emerging from the VOF technique. The water and air are simulated on the basis of a single-fluid formulation and the interface is implicitly defined. A validation study of this technique is presented.

To obtain an insight into the 3D flow effects the validated numerical procedure is applied to perform fully non-linear 3D slamming load calculations. These comprehensive results are then used to evaluate and compare the accuracy and performance of the traditionally used 2D formulations.

The slamming analysis is firstly performed for a fine-form Panamax container ship hitting a flat water surface at a constant trim angle. For this situation the results from the 3D slamming calculations are compared with results obtained by an integration of the line loads on 2D strips. The 2D analysis illustrates the effect of free-surface separations along the side of the bulbous bow. It is shown how this separation can create a new free surface which may cause a secondary slamming incident. The existence of this effect is investigated further in the 3D case.

Finally, for the same vessel sailing in a head sea characterized by a Pierson–Moskowich wave spectrum at half the service speed, the most likely (i.e. critical) wave episode associated with a given bending moment response level of the hull girder is identified. The described numerical procedure is first shown to be able to model this transient wave with sufficient accuracy. Thereafter a full 3D slamming calculation is performed.

sec.title: The slamming calculation procedure
sec.p: The determination of the slamming loads on ship hulls in heavy seas in a consistent manner is a real challenge. The main reasons are that the slamming loads are of a highly random nature; they are characterized by complex structural and water surface geometries, by high-pressure peaks acting during quite short time periods and by flow separation. Also, other physical phenomena such as trapped air and structural flexibility can in certain circumstances play a role.

Thus for predictive purposes it is necessary to introduce some simplifications into the problem. The most common way to simplify the calculations is to apply a strip theory for calculation of the relative motions between the hull and the water surface. The evaluation of the forces acting on the hull is then carried out by 2D analyses on each individual strip. The strip theory has shown its usefulness regarding estimations of the wave-frequency forces. Its application in a non-linear transient flow problem such as slamming has also been generally accepted, especially for slender monohulls such as modern container ships. However, the 3D effects of slamming are not yet fully known. Another uncertainty in applying a 2D approximation is related to the determination of the longitudinal extension of the slamming impact area. As a consequence, the results obtained by using a strip theory need supplements in terms of experimental data or empirical knowledge which may not be available in the conceptual design phase.

Many research studies have been carried out to reveal the effects of the structural stiffness, the flow separation and the 3D effects. Most of the former studies are restricted to 2D bodies, and the step necessary to be within reach of solving the problems in three dimensions is not so obvious. There are many challenges irrespetive of whether the approach is numerically, analytically or experimentally based. Faltinsen and Chezhian15 proposed a numerical approach utilizing the boundary element method (BEM) to predict the water-entry loads on 3D bodies. Their method was validated against drop test experiments and good agreement was found with respect to the maximum vertical forces and the peak load time. Beyond the peak load time the measurements show significant oscillations in the forces due to hydroelasticity effects.

The BEM has a wide range of applications, but it does have a few obvious limitations. One limitation is that the viscous effect cannot be accounted for and the flow separation is difficult to include in a consistent way in the calculation method.

As an alternative to the BEM, the VOF can be utilized to solve the impact problem. The work carried out by Muzaferija et al.16 and by Kleefsman et al.17 are two examples of the VOF approach. In this method, the water and air are simulated on the basis of a single-fluid formulation of the incompressible Navier–Stokes equations. In other words the two-phase mixture is modelled as a single fluid with discontinuous physical properties. A phase fraction function is then introduced to distinguish between the water and air.

In the following we shall outline the computational fluid dynamics (CFD) approach adopted here to study the 3D slamming impact on the forward part of a modern container ship with a bulbous bow. The simulations of the impact problem are performed using an implementation of the VOF method.

For the numerical solution an open-source CFD tool box OpenFOAM is used. This package is freely available on the internet and it provides necessary codes to carry out a full 3D slamming simulation. The code uses the finite-volume method to solve the partial differential equations which in this case are based on a VOF formulation to take into account the free surface and the possible complicated water splash-up during the impact. The flow is assumed to be incompressible and the hull structure is rigid; i.e. trapped air and flexible fluid–structure interactions due to an elastic structure are not accounted for in the simulation. It is not expected that the viscosity of the water has a significant effect on the results of the simulation. The flow is unsteady and because of the short duration of the impact it is assumed that there is no need for a turbulence model.

The focus of the present study is not on the numerical details but on the overall behaviour of the slamming phenomenon. For this reason the VOF implementation in OpenFOAM will be described only briefly. More details about the implemented VOF method can be found in the thesis by Rusche18 and in the source code.

In the applied procedure the momentum equation is formulated on the basis of a single-fluid formulation where the properties of the fluid are the results of the blending between the water and air. The density of water is denoted ρ1, and the density of air ρ2. The density that goes into the momentum equation is ρ which is calculated on the basis of the indicator function γ. Within a given control volume the indicator function is restricted to a value between 0 (100% air) and 1 (100% water). The indicator function can be considered as a time-dependent property of the fluid and moves with the fluid in a Lagrangian manner. The surface tension, in the following represented by Fs, is not so important in a water-entry problem.
Thus, in tensorial form, the flow continuity equations and the momentum equations on a fixed control volume implemented in the solver are

where γ∈[0,1] (air, γ=0 ; water, γ=1 ; mixture, 0<γ<1). The velocity field is U and the pressure field is p. Careful attention to discretizing and solving the transport equation (equation (1c)) is required in order to fulfil the boundedness criteria of γ and to preserve the sharpness of the interface between the water and air. Different techniques have been developed for a proper treatment of the convective term (the second term in γ equation (1c)), e.g. the compressive interface capturing scheme for arbitrary meshes,19 high-resolution interface capturing16 and piecewise linear interface calculation.20 The second technique utilizes a high-resolution compressive numerical scheme and the third technique is a method of geometrical interface reconstruction. In OpenFOAM the transport equation is handled using a technique described by Berberović et al.21 This technique will be briefly discussed here in order to explain the choice of the required parameters in the simulation. First, the scalar transport equation (1c) is reformulated to include an additional interface compression term that arises from two-phase flow consideration. The modified equation is

where Ur is the relative velocity between the water and air obtained from consideration of each phase, i.e. the water and air, separately. In a single-fluid formulation where the fluid property is averaged by the phase fraction the relative velocity Ur is zero by definition. However, it is reintroduced here and, furthermore, a third term is included to allow fine control of the numerical diffusion near the interface. The third term is only effective within the interface region where the value of γ is between 0 and 1. Away from the interface the value of γ will be either exactly or very close to 0 or 1 and the coefficient γ (1–γ) will cause the third term to vanish. The relative velocity Ur is not well defined and is to be chosen based on experience. Using a high value of Ur will yield a sharp interface. However, there can be potential numerical problems related to a very sharp discontinuity at the interface. Therefore, an appropriate choice of Ur is needed. Within every single control volume (finite-volume cell) the upper limit of Ur is set by the volume metric flux φ and the discretized version of Ur is taken as
where the face normal flux nf is given by

and where Sf is the face area vector of the control volume (finite-volume cell). The subscript f indicates that the value is to be evaluated at the cell face. nf is the unit normal flux of the interface and δn is very small constant introduced to prevent a ‘division by zero’ error during the estimation of the unit normal vector of the interface. The max( ) limiter returns the maximum face velocity of all faces on the control volume. The coefficient Cf is introduced for convenience so that the relative velocity can be controlled. Using too small a value of Cf yields an unacceptable smearing of the interface. It was found that, for the simulations presented in this paper, Cf = 1.5 yields a sufficiently sharp interface and yet not so sharp that it would cause a numerical instability due to the discontinuity of the interface.

The simulations presented in this study exploit the dynamic mesh motion functionality in OpenFOAM. In each time step a new mesh is generated using information about the movement of the moving boundaries which can be determined on the basis of their position or velocity. The method to generate the new mesh can be categorized as a deforming mesh method where the connectivity of grids remains unchanged. The displacement of each point on the grid is determined from solution of a Laplace equation with a variable diffusivity coefficient. A detailed description of this mesh motion technique has been given by Jasak and Tuković.22 The diffusivity coefficient can be defined in many ways and may depend on the particular mesh configuration and the distribution of the grid density. The goal, however, is to preserve the validity and the quality of the mesh. In the simulations presented in this paper the motion of the moving boundaries is prescribed and it was found that a distance-based diffusivity coefficient is usable with the applied mesh configuration, as shown by the equation

where u is the displacement, D is the variable diffusivity coefficient and l is the distance to the moving boundary. The relative movement of the points adjacent to the moving boundary is limited. The large deformations occur far from the moving boundary where the mesh is relatively coarse and the local mesh distortion is kept within an acceptable amount.
A second-order central differencing scheme is used for spatial discretization and interpolation. For the temporal integration an implicit Euler scheme was applied for maximum stability.

sec.title: Validation by comparison with experimental results
sec.p: Experimental measurements of the slamming forces on models of a bow section are available in the report by Aarsnes.23 These experiments were used here to validate the VOF flow solver provided by the OpenFOAM package. The same experimental data have been used by Brizzolaraa et al.24 to make a comparison between a number of commercial CFD codes with different numerical approaches such as the BEM, smoothed particle hydrodynamics as well as an implementation of a VOF method provided by the commercial CFD software packages FLUENT and FLOW-3D, all in two dimensions. One of the conclusions drawn by Brizzolaraa et al.24 was that the predicted pressures and forces and their variations with time are very sensitive to the velocity profile of the falling motion. Thus, to obtain a good comparison with the experiments it is required that the velocity profile is accurately predicted or prescribed using the measured motion data.

A sketch of the experimental set-up is shown in Figure 1. The 2D bow-flare section is 320 mm wide measured from edge to edge. The geometry of the bow-flare section was taken from the work by Aarsnes.23 The total computational domain is 2 m wide and the water depth is 1 m.

caption.p: The computational set-up for simulation of drop-test case 261 in the work of Aarsnes.23

sec.p: Basically there are two types of boundary condition applied in the simulation: walls and atmosphere. The no-slip velocity condition is imposed on the wall-type boundaries. These are at the side walls, the bottom and the surface of the bow-flare section. The ‘atmosphere’ boundary as indicated in Figure 1 has the total pressure set to zero, i.e. pd+12ρ|U|2=0, with pd defined as

where p is the total pressure, pd is the hydrodynamic pressure, and g and x are the gravitational vector and the position vector respectively. Note that the density ρ is the weighted average as shown in equation (1d) and may vary sharply near the water surface.

Figure 2 shows the shape of the section and the locations where the pressure was recorded and also the prescribed velocity profile applied in the numerical simulation. This velocity profile is obtained from the experimental data of case 261 in the work by Aarsnes.23 The heel angle is 0° and the estimated entry velocity is 2.43 m/s. As seen in the velocity profile, the bow section does not penetrate the free surface with a constant velocity, but instead it accelerates downwards with a nearly constant acceleration which from the figure is estimated to be 9.07 m/s2. After about 0.06 s the wetted surface has reached the upper flare and the velocity of the bow section starts to decrease rapidly.

caption.p: (a) Bow-flare section with measured pressure locations; (b) prescribed velocity. The measurement data were taken from the work of Aarsnes.23

sec.p: For the numerical simulation the fluid domain is discretized into finite-volume cells using an unstructured tetrahedral mesh. Despite the fact that there are many disadvantages in using a tetrahedral mesh in a VOF simulation such as slow convergence and numerical diffusion which put strict constraints on the size of the triangular elements, it is found that the use of tetrahedral cells is sufficient in this 2D simulation. With the open source software GMSH developed by Geuzaine and Remacle a body-fitted mesh can be easily generated. The characteristic length of the tetrahedral elements is defined so that the cells have a small size and a high density near the body and around the location where there are significant velocity gradients. A suitable mesh is found by performing a mesh convergence study and by making sure that the results do not depend on the grid density. The total number of the tetrahedral cells is approximately 174,000. It should be noted that the bow-flare section is symmetric and so is the flow. Thus the size of the computational domain could be reduced by half, but this is not done here.
The calculated water pile-up profiles are shown in Figure 3.

caption.p: The simulation of test 261 in the work of Aarsnes,23 showing the water pile-up profiles at 0 s, 0.025 s, 0.05 s and 0.075 s.

sec.p: The water surface is calm before the impact and the total impact time for simulation is about 0.1 s. The results from the pressure probes at four locations are shown in Figure 4. From the experimental results given by Aarsnes,23 it is not clear whether the reported pressures are the total pressures including the contribution of the hydrostatic pressures. Therefore estimates of the hydrostatic pressures are shown in Figure 4 together with the hydrodynamic pressures defined by equation (5).

caption.p: Comparison of measured pressures and numerically calculated pressures as functions of time at the four locations indicated in Figure 2.

sec.p: From Figure 4 it is seen that in general the agreement between the measured and the local pressure variations at different locations on the 2D bow section is fairly good. Approximately 0.06 s after the initial impact the computed pressures contain numerically induced high-frequency oscillations seen as pressure ‘spikes’ in Figure 4. There are many reasons that could cause the pressure to show a spiky behaviour. One of these may very well relate to the fact that tetrahedral cells were used to discretize the fluid domain. The general trend in the figures, however, agrees reasonably well with the experiments. The simulation starts at t = 0 s where the initial contact between the water and the bow section takes place. During the whole simulation, the location p1 is in contact with the water all the time and the computed pressure agrees almost perfectly with the measurement. At other locations such as p2, p3 and p4, the computed pressures depend on the accuracy of the prediction of the water uprise, i.e. the deformation of the free surface. The time at which the computed pressures begin to increase, which is seen at the locations p2, p3 and p4, agrees well with the experiment but the peak values are either overestimated (at p2 and p3) or underestimated (at p4) by 15–20%. It is well known that the prediction of a slamming pressure is a difficult task. There are several reasons that may explain this deviation. One of these is the accuracy of the computed film thickness of the water; another is the resolution of the free surface. It should also be noted that there are some variations in the measured peak pressures. Even if the conditions of the experiments such as the drop height, the heel angle and the friction inside the guide rail remain almost unchanged, the measurements may have some variation during a repeated test. The reason for this variation is not known to the present authors.

A comparison of the total impact force on the bow section is shown in Figure 5. The measurement contains a high-frequency oscillation which was considered by Aarsnes23 to originate from the drop rig. The computed vertical force increases smoothly until it reaches a peak value at approximately t = 0.06 s. Beyond the time of the peak value the vertical force shows signs of abrupt behaviour and spikes. These discontinuities are purely numerical owing to the quality of the grid and the discretized velocity profile. The spikes in the forces are inherited from the pressure field, as shown in Figure 4. Nonetheless, the simulation captures most of the interesting features of the time development of the vertical force. The results show clearly that, at least in a 2D case, the VOF formulation provided by the OpenFOAM package is capable of producing a favourable estimate of the impact force provided that the kinematics of the body motion during the impact are modelled accurately.

caption.p: The simulation of case 261 in the work of Aarsnes,23 showing a comparison of the total vertical force on the bow-flare section.

sec.p: To validate the performance of the numerical procedure also for 3D situations a comparison was made with some test results for a 30° wedge performed by Zhao et al.25 The wedge model used in the experiment has a beam width of 0.5 m and a total length of 1.0 m. The measuring section is 0.2 m in length located in the middle between two dummy sections. The actual size of the water tank is not known to the present authors. The dimension of the 3D wedge model and the size of the numerical tank are shown in Figure 6(a). In the 3D calculations the clearance to the side wall is set to 0.25 m.

caption.p: (a) A comparison between 2D and 3D numerical results and experimentally (from the work of Zhao et al.25) obtained slamming forces for a 30° wedge; (b) a sketch of the set-up in two dimensions.

sec.p: The results of the simulations together with the experimental results are shown in Figure 6. It is seen that, as expected, the 2D model overestimates the vertical slamming force, and that the 3D results with 1.3 × 106 cells predict the experimentally obtained forces as a function of time quite well. The 2D model overestimates the maximum force by about 20% in accordance with the findings made by Zhao et al.25

sec.title: Comparison of 3D and 2D bottom slamming and bow-flare slamming results
sec.p: The validated numerical procedure will in this section be applied to a container ship bow to estimate the pressure distributions as well as the overall slamming forces from a full 3D calculation procedure and to compare these results with slamming loads obtained by an integration of forces caused by the flow on 2D strips.

For the numerical experiments we shall use the hull form from the KRISO container ship (KCS),26 with the following main dimensions: Lpp = 230.0 m, Bwl = 32.2 m, D = 19.0 m, T = 10.8 m and a displacement of 52,030 m3.

This hull form represents a commercial fine-form container ship with a bulbous bow and a bow flare which is relatively modest compared with those of modern ships. The geometry of this hull is published with the intention of providing data for CFD validation as well as studying flow physics.

The forward part of this hull has an overall length of 100 m in the present study. A sketch is shown in Figure 7 including the subdivision into 2D strips with 5 m spacing used for the 2D calculations.

caption.p: Forward hull form of the KCS with the applied 2D strips with 5 m spacing.

sec.p: The comparison between the 3D and the 2D calculation results is made for a test case where the container vessel plunges with a vertical velocity of 10 m/s and no forward speed into a flat water surface with an initial negative trim of 10°. This situation and the calculation domain are shown in Figure 8.

caption.p: Drop simulation of a 3D bulbous bow ship section with an initial negative trim of 10° and a constant velocity of 10 m/s. The mesh density has five levels.

sec.p: Hybrid body-fitted meshes of hexagonal and split-hexahedra cells were used to discretize the domain and the complex 3D geometry of the ship hull. The fluid domain is dominated by the hexagonal cells except in those areas where it is necessary to introduce polygon cells in order to make the grid conform to the body and to obtain a reasonable transition between low-grid-density and high-grid-density areas. The grid density is defined so that there are five density levels, as sketched in Figure 8. The grid density is highest close to the body. The coarsest mesh area is level 0 which is furthest away from the body. The subsequent levels are defined relative to the characteristic size of level 0. The relation is Ln=L0/2n, where L0 and Ln are the characteristic size of level 0 and the characteristic size of level n respectively. For example, if the characteristic length of level 0 is 1 m, then the characteristic length of level 2 is L2=1/22=0.25 m. Next to the hull a mesh level 4 is defined. This produces a near-wall-cell size of L4=0.0625L0.

The resulting vertical force as a function of time obtained by the 3D calculation procedure is shown in Figure 9. It should be emphasized that the forces in Figure 9 are the hydrodynamic forces calculated by taking the total force and subtracting a nominal hydrostatic force. For consistency the nominal hydrostatic force is estimated on the basis of the displacement of the hull measured up to the initial calm waterline.

caption.p: Numerically calculated vertical hydrodynamic slamming force with a grid convergence study: coarse mesh (1.0 × 106 cells), medium mesh (4.2 × 106 cells) and fine mesh (19.8 × 106 cells).

sec.p: The results are depicted for three different mesh sizes, namely a coarse mesh with a total of 1 × 106 cells, a medium mesh size with 4.2 × 106 cells and finally a fine mesh with 19.8 × 106 cells. The corresponding near-body-cell sizes are approximately 0.37 m, 0.18 m and 0.09 m for the coarse mesh, the medium mesh and the fine mesh respectively. The computational effort needed to run the fine mesh in 3 s of the physical time is approximately 180 h on 40 cores of an Intel® Xeon® X5550 cluster. For the coarse mesh the execution time is approximately 5.5 h on 20 cores. It is noted that this convergence study shows that the mesh size mainly has an influence close to the peak of the hydrodynamic vertical force.

The initial impact occurs on the bulb and the high impact velocity causes the free surface to separate along the side of the bulb and to accelerate upwards towards the flare area, forming a cavity. At the bottom further aft the pressure builds up, forming a high-pressure spray root moving along the flat bottom in a similar way as known from wedge slamming. Eventually the spray root reaches the rear part of the truncated hull, causing the total force to fall as the high-pressure spray root leaves the flat bottom.

For the same test situation as described above, numerical calculations were performed on the basis of the traditional procedure where the total vertical hydrodynamic force is obtained by integration of the numerical results obtained from 2D calculations performed on the strips shown in Figure 7.

These results are shown in Figure 10(a). First, it is noted that the spiked behaviour of the 2D calculations is purely due to the numerical procedure in which each 2D section hits the water surface without any trim. With a flat bottom, a 2D simulation cannot account for the trim angle and the result is similar to a flat plate impact on still water. Thus the spikes become proportional to the segment length (5 m here). In order to remove this numerical problem a smaller segment could be used but then the calculation time will increase.

caption.p: (a) 3D (fine mesh) and 2D total vertical forces where the contribution from 18 2D strips can be identified; (b) integrated impulse for the 2D and 3D solutions.

sec.p: The impulse is shown in Figure 10(b). It is seen that the impulse obtained from the 2D procedure does not deviate much from that obtained from the much more expensive 3D calculation procedure shown in Figure 9. To give an idea of the calculation time for the 2D calculations it can be mentioned that each station uses approximately 0.2 × 106 cells, and that the execution time for each station is approximately 3 h, occupying one node (eight cores). Thus 16 stations on 16 nodes can be dealt with within 3 h. This has to be compared with the much larger computational effort for the 3D calculations mentioned above.

Even if the 2D procedure for the resulting impulse for this test case agrees quite well with the more consistent 3D calculation procedure, there are differences in the most forward sections of the hull when a comparison is made between the forces per unit hull length.

One such example is shown in Figure 11 for sections approximately 3% aft of the forward perpendiculars (FPs). Here a sharp peak in the vertical force per unit hull girder length in the 2D calculation is shown, which is caused by flow separation at the bulbous bow. It is seen that in the 2D calculation this pressure peak occurs when the separated water surface hits the upper part of the bow at a very small angle. In the 3D case this nearly perfect match between the water surface and the bow geometry usually does not occur.

caption.p: Comparison between the forces per unit hull girder length calculated by the 2D procedure and by the 3D procedure at station 3, approximately 3% from the FP (see also Figure 7).

sec.p: Figure 12 shows that for station 4, i.e. 5 m further aft, there is no separation of the flow in the 2D calculation and therefore the agreement between the 2D and the 3D calculations is quite good up to about 1.9 s. Thereafter the 3D procedure predicts a lower force per unit hull length. The reason for this discrepancy is that, in three dimensions, the pile-up water can travel in the longitudinal direction and it leaves the aft part of the truncated hull, causing a reduction in the overall pressure. The time that this occurs can be identified from the peak force level in Figure 10(a) (i.e. at approximately 1.49 s) as the magnitude of the total force falls dramatically after the spray root has moved beyond the end of the truncated hull.

caption.p: No free-surface separation during the bottom slamming at station 4, approximately 8% from the FP.

sec.p: The conclusion that we can draw from these numerical experiments is that separation of the flow caused by the bulbous bow can lead, especially in 2D calculations, to very small relative contact angles between the water and the bow structure, causing large local pressure peaks. Furthermore, the total impulse of the 3D calculation procedure and the 2D procedure based on integrations of strips are comparable in the present test case. This latter conclusion may be influenced by the fact that a container ship hull form without excessive bow flare is considered.

sec.title: Slamming event in a conditional wave
sec.p: To estimate the slamming pressures, accurately detailed information about the relative velocity between the water and the free-surface topology is needed in the region where slamming occurs. Therefore, instead of the simplified model where the ship plunges in a deterministic manner in a plane water surface or the other extreme of a full time simulation of the vessel in a stochastic sea, we shall in this section apply a more realistic wave sequence situation which can be used to identify the most probable extreme whipping loads. This so-called critical wave episode, or most likely response wave, described by Jensen,27 represents the most likely mean wave and ship motion associated with a given extreme wave hull girder bending moment response.

The critical wave episode calculation by Jensen27 was based on a time-domain non-linear strip theory calculation procedure described by Xia et al.,28 linked to a first-order reliability method (FORM) code. The hull is assumed to be rigid in the present study but the work by Jensen27 also contained similar results for a flexible hull. The vessel is assumed to be sailing at 5 m/s in a head sea in a long-crested sea state characterized by a Pierson–Moskowich wave spectrum with a significant wave height Hs = 10 m and a mean wave period of 11.35 s.

The result of calculations along the lines presented by Jensen27 is a most probable sea surface elevation and rigid body ship motion conditional on a sagging bending moment of 3000 MN m. These results are shown in Figure 13 as a function of time until the maximum bending moment response occurred at the pre-selected time (50 s) after initiation of the calculations. This time distance is sufficiently long to ensure that the transient effects from the arbitrary initial conditions in the simulations do not influence the maximum response. The resulting conditional wave elevation and wave kinematics are given as Fourier coefficients to a usual deep-water linear irregular potential wave representation, whereas the ship responses are given as time-domain signals due to the non-linear response calculation.

caption.p: Most probable wave scenario and associated ship response conditional on a sagging bending moment amidships equal to 3000 MN m.
BM: bending moment; FP: forward perpendicular.

sec.p: The FORM reliability index for this event is 2.7532, corresponding to a return period of approximately 10 min in this stationary sea state and the operational conditions. Thus, this is a rather frequent event and reflects the severity of the sea state but also that the design wave bending moment for this ship is about 4000 MN m, i.e. 33% higher than the target response. For this situation a CFD analysis of the slamming event is performed in the following.

Many approaches can be applied to generate waves in a numerical wave tank. One example is a flap-type wave generator. In the present simulation, the wave is generated by simply prescribing a potential wave solution at the boundary. For a first-order potential wave the velocity profile is defined up until the mean waterline. However, in the simulation the velocity profile at the inlet boundary is prescribed up until the instantaneous first-order free-surface elevation by applying the Wheeler stretching.

The simulation requires an appropriate way to deal with wave reflections occurring at the boundaries. The reflection from the outlet boundary occurs mainly because of the difficulty of simulating a far-field boundary condition. The computational domain needs to be truncated to an appropriate distance and the ideal wave outlet boundary will let the waves propagate freely without any disturbance to the flow field.

Wave reflection in the present simulation is minimized by introducing relaxation zones along the boundary. A relaxation technique originally developed for the potential flow theory and applied also in Boussinesq models29–31 is adapted and applied within the VOF framework. Within a predefined relaxation zone, the field variables, i.e. the velocity U and the indicator function γ, are relaxed according to
where

The subscripts targ and comp indicate the target value and the computed value respectively. The relaxation coefficient α is defined to be bounded between 0 and 1. Inside the computational domain, α has the value 0 and gradually grows towards the value 1 at the boundary. Δt is the time step and Δs is the local characteristic size of the grid. An example is given in Figure 14. At each time step the target field values are constructed and applied to the current result of the computed fields. At the outlet boundary, the target velocity is simply zero and the target γ field corresponds to still water.

caption.p: An example of the relaxation coefficient αtarg applied inside a relaxation zone.31σ is the non-dimensional normalized distance defined on the basis of the total length of the relaxation zone.

sec.p: Simulations that include a ship use a moving frame of reference which is stationary with respect to the forward-moving ship. Thus, a ship with a constant forward speed is modelled in the simulation as a stationary ship in a constant inflow current. In the numerical model the inlet is placed forward of the FP and the conditional wave is defined to propagate from the FP to the aft perpendicular (AP), i.e. assuming a head sea.

Since radiation and scattering waves will be generated owing to the presence of the vessel, there is a risk that the reflected waves travel towards the inlet boundary and interfere with the prescribed boundary conditions, causing numerical instability. Therefore, a relaxation zone at the inlet boundary is also required. At the inlet relaxation zone the target velocity is the expected wave velocity profile corresponding to the prescribed wave conditions at the inlet boundary, and the volume fraction field γ needs to be constructed according to the instantaneous target free surface. A first-order reconstruction of the γ field is applied in the simulation.

An example of a 2D simulation of the long-crested conditional wave is shown in Figure 15. The cell spacing is stretched to obtain a high resolution near the free-surface region, resulting in a total number of cells of 315,000. The first-order potential flow solution in Figure 13 is compared with the results of the present 2D simulation in Figure 15.

caption.p: The time variation of the conditional wave at different positions. The red dashed curve shows the linear potential solution; the solid black curve is the result of the OpenFOAM simulation.
AP: aft perpendicular; FP: forward perpendicular; MS: midships.

sec.p: At the inlet boundary, the potential flow solution is prescribed. The numerical wave probe located at the inlet boundary therefore shows the same result as the potential wave. Further downstream minor differences occur in the free-surface elevation. The simulated free-surface elevation tends to be slightly steeper with higher crest values in accordance with the fact that the simulation is fully non-linear while the potential solution is accurate only up to first order. Furthermore the simulated wave is a finite-depth wave with the Wheeler stretching velocity at the inlet boundary.

It was a concern that the applied Laplacian mesh morphing solution for the ship motion may cause the simulated wave to be too diffusive. However, the result of a simple test case comparing results from a static grid and a moving grid reveals that the dynamic mesh motion has no significant effect on the simulated wave. The overall relative difference is less than 0.2%.

The conditional wave presented in Figure 15 was derived on the basis of a Panamax container ship with Lpp = 270 m sailing at 5 m/s in a head sea. The original KCS was extended at the amidships section (i.e the parallel midship section is lengthened by 40 m) to reflect the same main dimension such that the conditional wave can be applied on the KCS in a 3D simulation and any additional slamming load can be estimated. The discretization of the domain yields 7.4 × 106 cells with a reasonable grid resolution in front of the ship to ensure a proper wave simulation. The heave and pitch motions corresponding to the conditional wave are prescribed to the modified KCS ship. The distribution of the dynamic pressure (see equation (5)) is shown in Figure 16. The position of the free surface is quite similar to the position in the conditional wave solution at the instant of the expected amidships hogging condition at t = 45 s (see Figure 13) and the expected maximum sagging condition at t = 50 s. A comparison of the bending moment can only be made qualitatively since the CFD calculation applies the forced rigid body motion derived by the strip theory. Consequently, dynamic equilibrium is not exactly achieved in the CFD results. This is reflected in the fact that the wave bending moment amidships calculated by integration from the aft end of the vessel is not completely the same as obtained by integration from the forward end. Without the dynamic equilibrium the moment contribution from the inertia force due to heave and pitch motions cannot be estimated accurately. In the planned future work the ship will be allowed to move freely.

caption.p: Dynamic pressures during severe heave and pitch motions.

sec.p: The largest heave and pitch motions occur in between t = 40 s and t = 50 s where the front part of the ship emerges slightly from the water surface at t = 43 s and re-enters at a wave trough at t = 45 s. The relative re-entry velocity at the wave trough is too small to cause any significant bottom slamming. However, a possible bow-flare slamming can be identified at t = 49 s and a stern slamming at t = 51 s. The occurrence of slamming can be better identified on the basis of a time series of the vertical force distribution, as shown in Figure 17. The duration of bottom slamming is expected to be less than 1 s. From Figure 17 the load on the 15% forward part of the vessel indicates a rise time of more than 2 s, which therefore can be interpreted as a sign of no severe bottom slamming. Overall, bow-flare slamming in the present wave conditions is moderate. This finding supports the fact that the KCS ship has a hull form with a sharp bulb and without an excessive bow flare.

caption.p: Time series of the vertical hydrodynamic force distribution between the AP (x = 0) and the FP (x = Lpp).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: It was the purpose of this study to investigate the accuracy of the present slamming load estimation procedure where a standard sea-keeping procedure is applied to determine the relative velocity distribution between the water surface and the hull surface and thereafter estimation of the bottom slamming loads and the bow-flare slamming loads based on 2D formulations similarly to water-entry problems. The analysis was performed by comparing 2D slamming results with results obtained from direct 3D, fully non-linear numerical calculations in a realistic conditional wave environment.

Both the global and the local slamming loads were assessed numerically using a finite-volume formulation with the free surface captured by a VOF technique. The applied flow equation is the incompressible Navier–Stokes equation with the additional transport equation emerging from the VOF technique. The water and air were simulated as a single fluid and the interface was implicitly defined.

A validation study of this numerical tool was performed by comparing numerical results with experimentally obtained slamming pressure variations for small-scale models. The conclusions from these validation analyses are that slamming loads can be assessed numerically using the applied finite-volume formulation with the free surface captured by a VOF technique.

However, it was also found that, in order to obtain reliable and converged results for 3D slamming analyses, the requirements with respect to the fineness of the calculation meshes are such that the computer resources needed are massive. This poses some limitations on the application of this numerical procedure for practical estimation of slamming loads. Thus, at present the 3D analysis procedure is best suited to derive or calibrate more approximate but faster procedures.

To obtain an insight into the 3D flow effects the validated numerical procedure was used to evaluate and compare the accuracy and performance of the traditionally used 2D formulations by a comparison with 3D numerical formulations for a Panamax container ship hitting a flat water surface at a certain trim angle.

Detailed numerical results from the 2D approach show interesting effects of free-surface separations at the bulbous bow during the bottom slamming. At certain conditions the free surface separates along the side of the bulbous bow, creating a new free surface relative to the bow-flare area. According to these 2D simulations the newly created free surface may cause severe local bow-flare slamming pressures. The existence of this effect was not found in the 3D case.

The main conclusion for the considered test case with a container ship hull form with a relatively small bow flare plunging into a flat water surface is that the overall results of the impulse in the 3D calculation procedure and in the 2D procedure based on strips are comparable.

Finally, a slamming evaluation is performed on the basis of a 3D case study of the same fine-form Panamax container ship but now sailing in a head sea at half the service speed in a critical wave episode which is defined conditionally on a given response level of the hull girder bending moment. The present calculation is capable of capturing effects not covered by standard strip theory calculations. Thus, it may be possible to transfer the results of the complex CFD simulations to the strip theory results using a model correction factor approach. Thereby, strip theory calculation in random seaways might be modified to take into account the complex hydrodynamics (i.e. slamming) only possible to analyse by CFD. However, further investigations are clearly needed before more precise conclusions can be stated and to determine whether such a robust procedure can be derived.

Such future work within this area should also include a re-formulation where the ships are free to move in the conditional wave. Thereby, a dynamic balance is ensured at all times. Furthermore, since the formulation does not utilize symmetry around a vertical plane, then the same numerical model could also be applied to analyse 3D unsymmetric slamming loads in an oblique sea and the resulting torsional impact loads on the hull girder. Furthermore, a more realistic ship hull form should be applied, reflecting the large bow flare in modern containerships. Finally, besides bow-flare slamming, also 3D stern slamming should be analysed in detail.

fn.p: This work was supported by the American Bureau of Shipping and by the Danish Maritime Fund (grant no. 2009-03).
